title: NOW H IL OPPOSES SPITZ PLAN. SAYS SHE'S AGAINST IMMIGRANT LICENSES
body:
WASHINGTON - Sen. Hillary Clinton tried to put her biggest stumble of the campaign in the rearview mirror 
yesterday by coming out against driver's licenses for illegal immigrants.

"As President, I will not support driver's licenses for undocumented people," Clinton (D-N.Y.) said, adding she "will 
press for comprehensive immigration reform that deals with all of the issues around illegal immigration."

She delivered her first unequivocal statement on the issue after Gov. Spitzer dropped the idea yesterday, a day 
before today's Democratic showdown in Las Vegas, where she hopes to get her front-runner's groove back.

Clinton hit her first serious bumpy stretch of the race two weeks ago at the Democratic debate in Philadelphia when 
she refused to say if she backed Spitzer's plan.

Analysts predicted there would not be a repeat of Clinton's Philly flubs in Vegas, and that she'd try to get back on 
the high road. "Her answers will not evolve over the course of a few minutes," said Marist College pollster Lee 
Miringoff, who found a tightening race after that debate.

"She's got to get back to the big issues - health care, Iraq, global warming - which is what the voters really want," 
he said.

In a preview of tonight's showdown, the campaign of Sen. Barack Obama (D-Ill.) served notice he won't just let the 
license issue go. "When it takes two weeks and six different positions to answer one question on immigration, it's 
easier to understand why the Clinton campaign would rather plant their questions than answer them," said Obama 
spokesman Bill Burton. Obama said he liked Spitzer's license plan.

The campaign of Connecticut Sen. Chris Dodd, who opposed Spitzer's idea, also hammered Clinton.

"It's flip-flopping cubed," said Dodd spokeswoman Colleen Flanagan, mocking Clinton's convoluted answers in 
Philadelphia. "She was for it before she was against it, before she was for it, before she was against it."

Camp Clinton responded by criticizing her rivals' tone and highlighting the new difference between Clinton and 
Obama on the license issue.


David Damore, a University of Nevada, Las Vegas, political scientist, said Clinton's "parsing of policy has made for 
sound bites, but people are making a calculation of strategic viability, and right now they think Clinton has the best 
chance of winning.

"The biggest threat for her is a repeat performance of the last debate," he added.
